title: Question 17

children: A 27-year-old woman is hospitalized with a 2-day history of bloody diarrhea associated with abdominal cramping. She attended a picnic 5 days ago and swam in an adjacent lake. She reports no fever. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.

On physical examination, temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, and pulse rate is 105/min. On abdominal examination, bowel sounds are present with diffuse tenderness to palpation but no guarding.
Which of the following infections is the most likely cause of this patient's illness?

, or STEC) that can cause hemorrhagic colitis with development of hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), as in this patient. These bacteria are transmitted by ingestion of undercooked beef, usually hamburger, or fecally contaminated food and water, including recreational lake water; fecal-oral transmission through exposure to infected animals is also possible. The incubation period is 3 to 4 days, and patients typically have visibly bloody diarrhea, crampy abdominal pain, and no fever; the latter is a distinguishing feature from other causes of bloody diarrhea. HUS develops in less than 10% of patients infected with EHEC and manifests as microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (schistocytes on peripheral blood smear), thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.
